bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Raymond O. Dart, April 7, 1948

div1.p: Hench expresses concern about security issues in setting up an exhibit.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Raymond O. Dart, April 7, 1948
div1.opener:
April 7, 1948
Colonel Raymond O. Dart
Director, Army Institute of Pathology
7th Street and Independence Avenue, S. W.
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Colonel Dart:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of March 30 and it is going to
be very difficult for me to conform to the requirements which your Com-
mittee on Exhibits has set up. I do not question the propriety of their
decision that all exhibits must be completed by 8 o'clock in the morning,
May 10, and remain intact until 2 p.m. May 15. However, I do not at the
moment see how I can possibly get the exhibit up until May 11. Unfor-
tunately, I have made commitments rather far in advance. I have to be in
Minneapolis May 6 and In New York on May 9. As General Chairman in charge
of an International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases to be held in New York
at the Waldorf in June, 1949, we have set May 9 for a very important com-
mittee meeting. I simply cannot get to New York before May 9. I am speaking
in Charlottesville, Virginia on the evening of May 10 and much of the material
which you are asking me to exhibit is now on loan at the University of Vir-
ginia. I can pick it up on May 10, speak in Charlottesville that evening and
arrive in Washington the morning of the 11th. I do not know of anybody that
I feel inclined to entrust the job of setting up this exhibit for me. Indeed
quite a lot of the material is here at home, the rest I have set up at the
University of Virginia. You might suggest that I merely ship it to someone
and let them set it up for me. This I greatly hesitate to do because of my
peculiar feeling toward the material. It has been entrusted to me by the
families of Doctor Reed, Lazear and others and I do not feel that I own it.
It is eventually to be permanently cared for probably in a little museum here in
the Mayo Foundation. The material is absolutely irreplaceable and is priceless.
Much of it is small, such as letters and medals which could easily be lost. I
realize that you might suggest that one of your associates accept the respon-
sibility for me but even so I do not feel too inclined to accept that arrange-
ment. I know that even in the best run institution important data occasionally
get lost. Two weeks ago in Cuba, Mr. John Moran one of Reed's first guinea pigs
sadly told me that the University of Virginia Museum had lost a letter which
was to him most precious, a letter of commendation from Reed to Moran written
in Reed's own handwriting. Although this letter was loaned to the University
of Virginia Library and was in direct charge of the Curator, it was loaned to
a professor in a class and disappeared.

If your committee will make an exception and allow me to set the
exhibit up myself the morning of May 11, well and good. You state that the
exhibit is to be kept intact until May 15. I understood this Congress lasted
until the 18th. I haven't yet thought out how I can retrieve my exhibit be-
cause I will have to leave Washington myself on the 13th but once the exhibit
is intact and set up, I am not as concerned about its loss as about the pos-
sible loss in transportation.

I have found out from Doctor Bulbulian, the man in charge of the
Mayo Clinic scientific exhibits that no one from this Clinic is presenting
any other exhibits at this Congress, therefore, I cannot put the material in
the hands of the usual Clinic personnel who set up special exhibits.
I would appreciate your further comments on my problem.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
uc: Sawyer
Gen. Reed
Dr. A.L. Hench
